reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust-gate patterns at phase transitions. The existing library element (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition) prescribes passing System 1's automatic assessment through visual consistency, familiar language, and explicit connection to the prior phase. The new element (Treat Due Diligence as Productive Refusal) prescribes designing the evaluation and onboarding phases to actively support the host's question sequence rather than bypassing it. Both recognize that the host's automatic assessment at each threshold determines whether they proceed.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence from Kahneman: System 1 continuously generates suggestions and System 2 never gets the chance to evaluate if System 1 flags a negative impression. New evidence from Campbell: 'Not all who hesitate are lost. The psyche has many secrets in reserve.' Kent's 12-question evaluation sequence (01:13-09:31) IS the System 1 assessment in verbal form -- each question tests whether the current threshold passes automatic legitimacy. Combined insight: the System 1 trust gate is not just a visual/UI phenomenon (library) but also a conversational and informational phenomenon (this run). The due-diligence host's questioning IS the trust gate, and the platform must serve it in both verbal and digital contexts.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the problem of host momentum loss in the post-call period. The existing library element (Design for the Depleted User) recognizes that hosts arrive at each phase with reduced cognitive capacity from prior phases. The new element (Structure the Post-Call Void with Scheduled Re-Engagement) identifies the specific void between the evaluation call and the first platform interaction as the highest-risk dropout moment. Both prescribe external structure to compensate for internal depletion.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence from Kahneman: ego depletion research showing depleted decision-makers default to denial (the parole judge study). New evidence from Campbell: 'Refusal of the summons converts the adventure into its negative. Walled in boredom, hard work, or culture, the subject loses the power of significant affirmative action.' Kent says 'I'll review it and I'll get back to you' (11:17) with no scheduled follow-up. Combined insight: the post-call void is both a depletion problem (the host's System 2 is exhausted from a 12-minute evaluation) and a structural problem (no external schedule to create momentum). The fix must address both: reduce cognitive load of the review process AND provide temporal structure.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the human-to-digital trust handoff. The existing library element (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) prescribes explicit priming during the call and echoing the call's language on the platform. The new element (Surface Vetting Evidence in the Proposal Interface) prescribes converting Frederick's verbal vetting description into visible platform evidence. Both recognize that trust built with a human must be inherited by the platform, not rebuilt from scratch.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence from Kahneman: priming research showing prior exposure shapes evaluation of subsequent encounters. New evidence from Campbell: Frederick as supernatural aid figure provides 'amulets' -- but the platform must inherit the protective power. Kent's vetting question (04:56) was answered by Frederick verbally; the platform must now deliver the same answer visually. Combined insight: continuity priming is not just about visual/language consistency (library) but about evidence delivery consistency (this run). The platform must show the SAME evidence Frederick described, in the SAME categories Frederick named, or the trust bridge breaks.

reinforcements.similarity: The new communicates-014 (Guardian-to-Platform Trust Continuity) directly implements the existing works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) at the information architecture layer. Both prescribe maintaining the agent's identity and voice across digital touchpoints to preserve human trust in the digital context.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the platform's first screen should reference the call, show the agent's name and photo, and frame digital as continuation of human. New evidence from Campbell: the supernatural aid figure 'represents the benign, protecting power of destiny' and the hero must feel this power persists. Kent received Frederick's personal phone number (11:00) and all artifacts from Frederick personally. Combined insight: the continuity priming principle applies at every layer -- process (works-004), information architecture (communicates-014), visual (looks-011), interaction (behaves-006), and emotional (feels-007). This run provides the full-stack implementation of a principle the library identified at the process level.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the host's need for trust-building artifacts at phase transitions. The existing library element prescribes passing System 1's automatic assessment with visual consistency and familiar language. The new element (Provide Phase-Specific Protective Artifacts Before Each Threshold Crossing) prescribes delivering specific documents (success stories, contracts, vetting reports) at each phase boundary. The library element addresses the perceptual layer of the transition; the new element addresses the informational layer.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: System 1 assessment happens in under 2 seconds and requires continuity signals. New evidence: Kent requests specific artifacts at specific thresholds -- success stories at evaluation (06:16), contracts at onboarding (09:24), policies at listing (10:02). Campbell: 'the hero-journey is with a protective figure who provides the adventurer with amulets.' Combined insight: phase transitions need both perceptual continuity (library) and informational protection (this run). A visually consistent transition that lacks the relevant protective artifact will still fail the due-diligence host.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the speed of information delivery relative to the host's expectations. The existing library element (Match the Platform's Cognitive Speed to the Phone Call's Conversational Speed) prescribes matching platform interaction speed to the phone call's natural pace. The new element (Make the Herald's Credibility Verifiable Within 60 Seconds) prescribes making credibility verifiable within 60 seconds of first contact. Both share the principle that the platform must match the speed expectations set by human conversation.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas describes two units in 7 seconds; platform must match this density. New evidence: Kent needs company age, founder background, and track record verifiable in 60 seconds. Campbell: the herald must create 'irresistible fascination' immediately or the call goes unanswered. Combined insight: speed matching applies not just to data entry (library) but to trust verification (this run). The due-diligence host's speed expectation is: 60 seconds to verify credibility, 15 seconds per evaluation question, 2 minutes per protective artifact.

contradictions.conflict: The new looks-008 element specifies using accent color (#2d5a3d, warm green) for data points on evidence ladder rungs. However, the MEMORY.md notes a known token drift: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) but production uses purple (#31135D). This means the visual patterns in this run are designed for the token system's green palette, which may not match the production purple palette.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The tokens.json file explicitly defines accent as #2d5a3d (green), and all contrast calculations in this run's looks-elements are based on this value. The production purple (#31135D) would produce different contrast ratios. The tokens.json is the authoritative design system document, but production has drifted. Neither has stronger evidence -- this is a system inconsistency that predates this run.
contradictions.recommendation: Flag for human review. Either update tokens.json to reflect production purple, or update production to match tokens.json green. All runs including this one have designed against the green palette in tokens.json. If production uses purple, all contrast calculations and visual harmony assumptions need re-verification.

extensions.gap_filled: Due-diligence host archetype recognition. The existing library has no element that identifies the due-diligence host as a distinct behavioral archetype requiring differentiated treatment. All prior runs treat the host as a general user. This element establishes that systematic questioning is a host personality type, not a sales objection, and prescribes designing the evaluation flow to serve this archetype specifically.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Kent + Campbell), but the pattern is strongly evidenced by Kent's 12-question sequence. Need additional due-diligence host calls to confirm this is a recurring archetype, not an individual personality.

extensions.gap_filled: Host control boundary preservation. No existing library element addresses the host's need to set non-negotiable participation terms that the platform enforces. This element recognizes that minimum stay, guest requirements, and availability constraints are identity-level boundaries, not configurable preferences, and that violating them destroys trust irreversibly.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Kent's rejection of 6-week stays is strongly evidenced (09:46), but whether this is a common host concern or specific to Kent requires additional call data.

extensions.gap_filled: Sequential evidence ladder as information architecture pattern. No existing library element specifies the natural question sequence that due-diligence hosts follow during evaluation, or prescribes structuring information architecture to match this sequence. This element maps Kent's 12-question hierarchy to a 6-rung evidence ladder: proposition, credibility, economics, vetting, commitment, verification.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The question sequence is derived from one call, but its hierarchy (identity -> credibility -> economics -> risk -> commitment -> verification) follows rational evaluation theory, suggesting it would recur across due-diligence hosts.

extensions.gap_filled: Phase-boundary artifact delivery timing. No existing library element specifies WHEN protective documents should be delivered relative to the phase transition they protect. This element maps each phase boundary to a specific fear and a specific artifact that neutralizes it, prescribing delivery at the boundary moment rather than in batches.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Kent's artifact requests are temporally specific (success stories during evaluation, contracts during onboarding), but the mapping to Campbell's amulet framework strengthens the theoretical basis.

extensions.gap_filled: Post-call momentum architecture. No existing library element addresses the information architecture of the post-call review period specifically. This element prescribes replacing the unstructured document dump with a sequenced, time-bound delivery path: success stories (Day 1), contract (Day 2), policies (Day 4), follow-up call (Day 5-7).
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The post-call void is strongly evidenced by Kent's 'I'll get back to you' (11:17) and Frederick's batch document delivery. The sequencing prescription is theoretical (derived from Campbell's Departure sequence) and needs A/B testing.

extensions.gap_filled: Distinct visual pattern for protective artifacts (artifact card with left accent border). No existing library visual element defines a specific container pattern that differentiates threshold-crossing documents from generic content. This element creates a visual vocabulary for 'this protects you' using the forest green accent stripe.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The visual pattern is well-specified against tokens.json but needs usability testing to verify that users learn the accent-stripe association.

extensions.gap_filled: Vetting evidence display pattern. No existing library visual element specifies how guest vetting data should be presented in the proposal interface. This element creates a 2x2 verification grid with color-coded backgrounds (accent-light for passed, signal-warn-bg for flagged) and a persistent payment guarantee footer.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The four vetting categories are derived from Frederick's description (04:56-05:05) and match Kent's stated information needs. The visual pattern needs validation with hosts who have different vetting priorities.

extensions.gap_filled: Artifact reveal interaction pattern. No existing library interaction element specifies how protective documents should animate on reveal. This element prescribes an optimistic reveal (container appears in 0-120ms, content cascades in 120-400ms) that keeps the protective shape visible even during loading.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The timing specifications are derived from interaction design best practices and Campbell's amulet ceremony metaphor. Needs prototyping to validate perceived smoothness.

extensions.gap_filled: Engagement-responsive post-call delivery sequence. No existing library interaction element specifies the behavioral logic for multi-day follow-up sequences that adapt to host engagement signals. This element prescribes triggering subsequent deliveries based on host engagement with the previous one (plus 18-hour cooldown), with re-engagement pings at 48 hours and agent escalation at 96 hours.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The engagement-responsive logic is sound but complex to implement. Needs engineering feasibility assessment and A/B testing against fixed-calendar delivery.

extensions.gap_filled: Emotional design for the due-diligence host archetype. No existing library emotional element addresses the specific emotional needs of hosts who evaluate through systematic questioning. This element establishes that the target emotion during evaluation is confidence in their own judgment, not excitement about the opportunity, and prescribes a factual-respectful-unhurried voice.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Strongly evidenced by Kent's emotional posture throughout the call and validated by Frederick's best response moment (09:19: 'Yeah, for sure. Makes total sense.'). Needs confirmation across multiple due-diligence host calls.

extensions.gap_filled: Emotional framing of protective artifacts. No existing library emotional element distinguishes the emotional function of threshold documents (shields) from their informational function (brochures). This element prescribes framing artifacts with language that makes their protective function explicit: 'here is the agreement that protects your property' rather than 'here is our rental agreement.'
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The shield vs. brochure distinction is derived from Campbell's amulet metaphor and validated by Kent's artifact requests being tied to specific fears. Needs qualitative testing to verify emotional impact of reframed language.

new_tokens_flagged: rung-divider: proposed in looks-008 for evidence ladder rung separation (could reuse border token with vertical margin)
artifact-border-width: 4px left-border proposed in looks-009 for protective artifact card accent stripe
vetting-pass-bg: proposed semantic alias for accent-light (#e8f0eb) in vetting context (looks-012)
vetting-flagged-bg: proposed semantic alias for signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) in vetting context (looks-012)
progress-connector: proposed in looks-013 for step-to-step visual connection in progress indicator
token_compliance.recommendation: The rung-divider and progress-connector tokens can be achieved with existing border token (#e2dfd9) and custom spacing -- no new color tokens needed. The artifact-border-width (4px) is a new dimension value not in the current spacing scale (xs=4px exists but semantically different). Consider adding a 'border-width' sub-scale to tokens.json. The vetting-pass-bg and vetting-flagged-bg are semantic aliases for existing colors (accent-light, signal-warn-bg) -- recommend adding them as aliases rather than new values to maintain palette coherence. No new colors are proposed; all visual patterns use the existing palette correctly.

arc_conflicts: No direct arc conflicts detected. The emotional arc for this lens is consistently conservative: safety -> confidence -> control -> calm. This contrasts with the typical marketing emotional arc (excitement -> engagement -> delight) but is appropriate for the due-diligence host archetype. The arc never requires excitement, which is unusual but coherent with Kent's personality -- he is motivated by evidence, not aspiration.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is coherent end-to-end and specifically tuned to the due-diligence host archetype. It moves from external safety (credibility verification in discovery/evaluation) through internal confidence (host's trust in their own judgment during listing/pricing) to settled calm (the guardian persists through active lease). The arc's distinctive feature is that it NEVER targets excitement -- Campbell's Departure sequence is about courage through evidence, not enthusiasm. This is a valid emotional journey for thorough, risk-averse hosts. However, the arc may need supplementation for hosts who are NOT due-diligence types -- impulsive or excitement-driven hosts may find this arc too conservative. The library should eventually contain multiple emotional arcs for different host archetypes.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The works layer identified the due-diligence host archetype but did not produce a process pattern for retention-phase re-engagement of this archetype. Kent's personality predicts he will re-evaluate the platform after his first lease with the same thoroughness he applied initially. A works-level element for 'due-diligence retention evaluation' is needed.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Campbell's Return phase (not included in this book extract, which covers only the Departure) would provide the theoretical framework for how the hero decides to re-enter the adventure. A future run with Campbell's Return chapters would fill this gap.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The looks layer produced visual patterns for evaluation and proposal management but did not produce a visual pattern for the retention-phase dashboard that would show the due-diligence host their first-lease outcomes versus expectations. Kent will want a data-driven comparison: 'Here is what happened versus what Frederick promised.'
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Retention-phase visual patterns should show: actual payment timing versus promised 4-week cycle, actual guest vetting outcomes, and total earnings versus what Kent would have earned through traditional rental. This is the evidence the due-diligence host needs to decide on re-listing.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The feels layer's emotional arc never targets excitement, which is appropriate for the due-diligence host but leaves a gap for non-due-diligence host archetypes. A future run should examine whether the library needs parallel emotional arcs for different host personalities.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: A call transcript from an impulsive or excitement-driven host (the opposite of Kent) would reveal whether the current library's emotional elements are too conservative for some host segments.
